title: Employee Surveillance Productivity Paradox
context: With the shift to remote work, companies deploy employee monitoring software — keystroke loggers, screenshot capture, mouse movement tracking, application usage monitoring. The stated goal: ensure remote workers are productive. The actual result: employees optimize for appearing busy rather than being productive. They jiggle their mouse, keep apps open, and perform visible-but-meaningless work. Trust collapses. The best employees leave for companies that treat them like adults. Surveillance doesn't measure productivity — it measures compliance with surveillance.
hypothesis: Employee monitoring software ensures remote workers are productive.

effects.label: Employees optimize for surveillance metrics, not actual output
effects.impact: Visible activity increases, meaningful output doesn't

children.label: Mouse jigglers and activity simulators become common
Employees keep monitored apps open while doing nothing productive
Time spent on 'looking busy' displaces time spent on actual work

effects.label: Trust between employer and employee collapses

children.label: Surveillance signals 'we don't trust you' — employees reciprocate
Psychological safety destroyed — people hide mistakes instead of learning from them
Discretionary effort disappears — employees do the minimum to satisfy metrics

effects.label: Top performers leave — they have options and won't tolerate surveillance
effects.impact: Voluntary attrition increases 25-35% among high performers

children.label: Best engineers go to companies that measure output, not keystrokes
Remaining workforce skews toward those who can't leave
Employer brand damaged — word spreads about surveillance culture
Captured screenshots may contain personal information — GDPR/privacy violations
Keystroke logging captures passwords and personal communications

dontIf: Your employees are knowledge workers whose output can't be measured by keystrokes
You're deploying surveillance because you don't trust your hiring decisions
ifYouMust: Monitor outcomes (deliverables, milestones) not inputs (keystrokes, mouse movement)
Be fully transparent about what's monitored and why
Give employees the ability to pause monitoring for personal time
Use aggregate data for process improvement, not individual surveillance

alternatives.name: Output-based management
alternatives.note: Define clear deliverables and deadlines — measure what gets done, not how long someone sits at a desk

alternatives.name: Regular 1:1 check-ins
alternatives.note: Weekly conversations about progress and blockers — builds trust and catches issues early

alternatives.name: Team-level metrics
alternatives.note: Track team velocity and outcomes rather than individual activity — aligns incentives
